name: Jemaa el-Fnaa
description: Lively square offering food stalls, musicians, and street performers

name: Hassan II Mosque
description: One of the world’s largest mosques with an oceanfront location

name: Bou Inania Madrasa
description: 14th-century Islamic school known for its stunning architecture

name: Kasbah of the Udayas
description: Historic kasbah with ocean views and Andalusian gardens

name: Blue Street
description: Iconic narrow street painted entirely in shades of blue

name: Skala de la Ville
description: Seaside ramparts with old cannons and stunning Atlantic views

name: Souk El Had
description: Large traditional market with spices, textiles, and crafts

name: Heri es-Souani
description: Granary and stables built by Sultan Moulay Ismail

name: Atlas Studios
description: Film-themed hotel inside the world’s largest film studio

name: Cape Spartel
description: Dramatic cape where the Atlantic meets the Mediterranean

name: Majorelle Garden
description: Vibrant botanical garden once owned by Yves Saint Laurent

name: The Corniche
description: Beachfront walk lined with cafes, clubs, and restaurants

name: Chouara Tannery
description: One of the world’s oldest tanneries with traditional leather dyeing pits

name: Mohammed VI Museum
description: Modern art museum showcasing Moroccan and international works

name: Ras Elma Waterfall
description: Popular local waterfall with scenic views and cool breezes

name: Essaouira Citadel
description: Historic sea fort offering great views of the Atlantic coast

name: Agadir Oufella Ruins
description: Hilltop ruins of a former fortress with panoramic city views

name: Bab Mansour Gate
description: Majestic gate known for its intricate tile work and arches

name: Aït Benhaddou
description: UNESCO-listed mudbrick village used in many Hollywood films

name: Place du 20 Aout Taroudant
description: Red-Hued walls, spanning 6-8 km, are adorned with watchtowers and punctuated by various gates
